Resilience activities will also be incorporated into the recovery programme, targeted in affected communities to mediate further loss.---Emergency Food and Nutrition Assistance in-kind or cashOn 10 May, WFP mobilized its area office within three hours of the floods to dispatch and distribute fortified biscuits to flood-affected populations and lipid-based nutrient supplements LNS for blanket distribution in all affected locations. Subsidised bread rations were also provided.

UNICEF is also developing a costed response plan primarily focusing on the most flood affectedprovinces in the northern and western regions.UNICEF ResponseHealth and Nutrition  To date, the UNICEF-supported health teams have treated a total of 11,4292 people 48 per cent children. The flooding has had a significant impact on women and children. UNICEF continues to provide health care services in the affected areas through mobile health and nutrition teams MHNTs. Five tents have also been provided to augment the existing health facilities and to be used by the mobile health teams.

UNICEF will provide an additional 78 HPTs, 161 floormats, 80 whiteboards and markers, 137 teacher kits and 227 students kits to 23 public schools affected by flooding in four districts of Baghlan province. UNICEF has provided support to three flood affected CBEs enabling children to resume their learning in the most flood affected districts. These classes are accommodating 85 children 45 girls and 40 boys in Sheikh Jalal and Karkar villages in Baghlani Jadid and Puli Khumri districts in Baghlan province. To date, 900 people 70 children have received mental health and psychosocial support MHPSS and information on wellbeing and explosive ordinance risk education EORE through UNICEF supported Implementing Partners.

WHO plans to deploy additional Surveillance Support Teams SSTs to enhance active disease surveillance in the affected districts. This will allow for early detection and timely response to potential outbreaks of communicable diseases, particularly waterborne illnesses.Health Cluster partners deployed Mobile Health and Nutrition Teams MHNTs to provide emergency healthcare services to the affected communities. In Ghor province, eight MHNTs have been deployed to the districts of Ferozkoh, Dolayna, Murghab, Shahrak and Tolak. Additionally, the Health Cluster partners have deployed five MHNTs to Bilcheragh, Pashtun Kot, and Maimana districts of Faryab province.United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs  Afghaistan  3In Faryab province, efforts are underway to repair and rehabilitate two health centers that have been destroyed.

WHO's field team is gathering information to determine the type and scale of additional required support. Including at least one female health worker or female psychosocial counselor in each response team is essential, as the affected population is predominantly women and children. Safety measures such as chlorine are in place.

While assessments are ongoing for both provinces, initial reports indicate the large-scale floods have resulted in the deaths of at least 120 people with hundreds more people missing and extensive damage to private properties and civilian infrastructure. Humanitarian partners and local authorities anticipate the number of casualties will increase significantly as search and rescue efforts continue amid reports that people may be trapped under collapsed buildings.

title: Afghanistan Flooding Situation Report No. 5 17 - 20 May 2024  content: Key messages: WHO has activated the Incident Management Team IMTsystem to assess the impact of the new floods in western and northern Afghanistan, affecting six additional provinces so far and causing significant damage to tens of villages and districts. Several health facilities providing essential health and nutrition services in the western region are currently partially or non-operational due to extensive flood damage. WHO successfully transported a significant consignment of 30 metric tonnes of essential medicines, medical kits, tents, and solar lights to the most affected Ghor province in the western part of the country.

title: Afghanistan Flooding Situation Report No. 6 21 - 23 May 2024  content: Key messages: Emergency response operations have been intensified in Baghlan, Badakhshan, and Takhar provinces, Northeast Afghanistan, following heavy rainfall on the 10th  11th of this month. title: Afghanistan: Countrywide Weekly Market Report: Issue 200: Week 3 May 2024  content: HighlightsIn the third week of May 2024, the prices of all food items, except for pulses, bread, and salt, negligibly decreased compared to the previous week. This downward trend in the prices of staple foods, particularly wheat flour, rice, and cooking oil, is attributed to a marginal decline in their global prices. Overall, most of the food items show a significant decrease compared to the prices observed during the same period last year.However, compared to the pre-COVID period, the national average prices of food items excluding wheat grain and wheat flour remain significantly higher. Similarly, compared to June 2021, before the political changes in the country, the prices of all other food itemsexcept wheat, wheat flour, and cooking oilcontinue to be significantly elevated.The national average exchange rate between the Afghani AFN and the US Dollar USD has remained relatively stable since November 2023, fluctuating between AFN 70 and AFN 74 per USD.

title: DTM Afghanistan: Weekly Flow Monitoring Snapshot 12 - 18 May 2024  content: OVERVIEWIOM Afghanistan's DTM Flow Monitoring activity, initiated at the beginning of 2024, seeks to quantify and better understand the mobility dynamics at Afghanistan's borders. On 10 January 2024, DTM began deploying field teams at four border crossing points with the Islamic Republic of Iran IRN and Pakistan PAK, expanding to another border crossing point Ghulam Khan as of 11 February see map below for the locations of all five crossing points, to conduct two interlinked exercises. The first is a headcount of all individuals entering or leaving Afghanistan including returnees, also called Flow Monitoring Counting FMC, to gauge flow volume. The second is a survey of randomly selected Afghan national individuals or groups entering or leaving Afghanistan, also called the Flow Monitoring Survey FMS, to understand the profiles, motivations, and vulnerabilities of the target population.

title: Guideline on Food Security and Agriculture Cluster Response Packages  content: Guideline on Food Security and Agriculture Cluster Response PackagesThe Food Security and Agriculture Cluster FSAC has been a central part of the humanitarian response in Afghanistan. The FSAC is co-led by the World Food Program WFP and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations FAO, with a non-governmental organization NGO, currently WHH as Co-chair.FSAC response strategy 2024 includes food assistance through cash and in-kind modalities, agriculture kit, vegetable kit, livestock kit, ruminants and poultry, and livestock vaccination. It is important to use a uniform approach as per minimum acceptable humanitarian standards across the country where relevant to avoid inequality, harm, and improper utilization of already stretched resources. In case of significant change in the context like vulnerability or market price changes, the packages need to be better explained to justify humanitarian intervention.

title: Severe flooding in Afghanistan hunger hotspots is set to worsen, warns WFP  content: KABUL: The United Nations World Food Programme WFP warns that the devastating floods that struck the Northeastern and Northwestern regions of Afghanistan in the past two weeks, impacting more than 80,000 people, are likely to intensify in the coming months, with a significant impact on food security. The affected districts, most of which are "hunger hotspots", are already in crisis levels of food insecurity.The worsening climate crisis has led to erratic weather patterns, which have become the norm across the country. Unusually high rainfall, which followed a dry winter that left the ground too hard to absorb rain, led to massive floods earlier this month. This was further compounded by unseasonably warm temperatures that melted mountain snow, swelling rivers that then swept through villages, burying them under mud.

title: Trkiye sees off another aid train for flood-hit Afghanistan  content: The "Goodness Train" organized by Trkiye's Disaster and Emergency Management Authority AFAD departed from Ankara's main train station on Tuesday. The train carries an assortment of humanitarian aid collected in a campaign by AFAD and 17 nongovernmental organizations NGOs for flood victims in Afghanistan.This is the 20th such train carrying aid for the Asian country whose economy is in tatters. The train's load includes 600 tents, food, hygiene kits, beds and blankets. In total, it carries 619 tons of aid.Deputy Interior Minister Mnir Karalolu, AFAD Chair Okay Memi and representatives of Turkish charities attended a ceremony to see off the train.
